awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A novel clutch mechanism for a more intuitive, stable prosthetic knee
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to help more amputees walk safely with less effort. Approximately 800,000 individuals live with a major lower limb amputation, and this number is growing largely due to diabetes. The 50,000 amputees each year who need a new prosthetic knee have two options:  learn to use a traditional prosthetic knee or attempt to obtain a high-tech, computer-controlled knee. The first option requires that the amputee learn and execute specific technique(s) to walk safely, while the latter does so automatically but cost $30,000-100,000 and requires physical qualification, limiting the availability. The novel prosthetic knee developed here offers stability automatically, regardless of amputee technique. It prevents buckling while simultaneously allowing the user to walk safely with any leg motions the user is able to generate. Since it requires no electronics or power, it is available to all amputees regardless of ability, and at a fraction of the cost of high-tech knees. Amputees will be able to walk farther with less effort, improving health and quality of life, and easing caregiver burden. Additionally, this design could be adapted for use in orthotic, robotic or exoskeletal systems.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project proposes to develop and test a novel prosthetic knee. This project will explore the trade space of mechanical and analytical capabilities.  This project will validate intuitive movement and universal stability for above-knee amputees through its innovative swing- and stance-phase functionality. This work will advance the knowledge of prosthetics, rehabilitation and bipedal locomotion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Every year in the US, 60,000 people lose a leg above the knee, and that number will double by 2050 largely due to diabetes. To walk again, an amputee will need either a mechanical or microprocessor-controlled (MP) prosthetic knee. Existing mechanical knee stability typically comes from alignment with respect to the ground reaction force (GRF), the amputee’s control of remaining muscles, or a combination. Such knees can be thought of as defaulting to “unstable” or swing mode, and this presents a learning curve to overcome:  the amputee must successfully execute a specific technique at a specific joint and at a specific time to achieve stability. In contrast, MP knees automatically turn “on” the stability control at the appropriate time, and default to stability mode most of the time. While this does yield benefits, MP knees are expensive ($30,000 - $100,000) and Medicare functional levels for amputation are used in prescribing them – meaning amputees must qualify physically to be eligible. As a result, only about 10% of amputees will ever receive an MP knee.

A gap exists in present technology for a knee that provides automatic stability similar to MP knees, yet is a passive mechanical device accessible to all amputees. The Xonotiv Knee provides intuitive and universally available stability (defined as prevention of unwanted flexion when weighted at any angle) with no need for expensive power or electronics and no need for the user to learn and execute particular knee-stabilizing techniques, braking actions, or joint moments. It incorporates a two-way overrunning clutch that defaults to stability mode yet is a low-cost mechanical device. The resulting clutching action makes this device innovative compared to current technology. It offers stability automatically and regardless of alignment, joint angles or GRF locations, all without the hydraulics, pneumatics, or electronics of higher-functional-level prostheses. Taken together, these attributes should improve walking and sit-to-stand performance, and provide stability on uneven ground, particularly for low-ability amputees.

The purpose of this Phase II project was to construct and test several prototypes of the Xonotiv Knee, culminating in a commercializable product ready for manufacturing. The results demonstrate that the Xonotiv knee safely supports the weight of human amputees, and provides intuitive and universally available stability without the need for power, electronics, or specialized user techniques. Manufacturing of the product is underway.

 


Last Modified: 02/27/2025
Modified by: Paul Pomeroy
